Humour out of breath. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1608. Date first performed: 1607-1608.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Antonio Aspero Flamineo Hermia Florimell Francisco
Hippolito Hortensio Julio Page Lucida Messenger Boy Octavio Prologue Assistant Lord Combined speech

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.p: Worthless sir, I present you with these my unperfect labours, knowing that what defect in me or neglect in the Printer hath left unperfect, judgment in you will wink at, if not think absolute. Being to turn a poor friendless child into the world, yet sufficiently featured too, had it been all of one man's getting, (woe to the iniquity of Time the whilst) my desire is to prefer him to your service: in which, as he shall be sure to get nothing, so likewise my hope is, he shall not lose much: For your bounty neither makes strangers love you, nor your followers envy you: you are a Patron worthy the Sister-hood, I mean, the poor half dozen, for the Three Elders, they climb above my element: the Sun, the Moon, and the seven Stars being scarce worthy the survey of their workings: I protest I had rather bestow my pains on your good worship for a brace of Angels certain, than stand to the bounty of a Better-mans Purse-bearer, or a very good woman Gentleman-usher: my reason is I cannot attend: your Bis dat, qui citae stands so like a Load-stone over your great gate, that I fear, it will draw all the Iron-pated Muse-mongers about the town in a short time to your patronage. For mine own part I had rather be yours volens, than be driven Nolens: So till I meet you next at your great Castle in Fish-street, I will neither taste of your bounty, nor be drunk to your health. One of your first followers, Iohn Daye.

div2.stage: Main text Humour out of breath. A Comedie
ACTUS I. Scena. I. Enter Octauio Duke of Venice, Hippolito and Francisco his sonnes, Florimell his daughter: Hortensio and others attendants.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Sons, hopeful buds of fruitful Italy,
Having banished war which like a prodigal
Kept wasteful revels with our subjects blood:
Since proud Anthonio our arch-enemy
Is in his journey towards the underworld,
Or hovers in the shade of banishment;
Let us in peace smile at our victory,
And every breast pass his opinion
What pastime best becomes a conqueror.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What sport but conquest for a conqueror,
Then with our wounds undressed, our steeds still armed,
Branded with steel ere we wipe off the blood
Of conquered foes, let us with our shriller bugles
Summon the surly Landlord of the forest,
The Kingly Lion to a bloody parley,
Combat the Hart, the Leopard or the Bore,
In single and adventurous hardyment:
The spirit of mirth in manly action rests,
Having quelled men let us now go conquer beasts.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Manly resolved; Hippolitoes advice.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Rather like soldiers, and Octauioes sons,
Let us throw a general challenge through the world,
For a proud tourney, at the which ourselves
Consorted with a hundred of our knights,
Accoutred like so many Gods of war,
Will keep the lists against all adventurers,
Which like the suns light figured in a star,
Should be a brief Epitome of war.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Noble and royal, your opinion daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faith I shall anger soldiers, I would pour
Spirit of life, Aurum Potabils
Into the jaws of chap fallen scholarship,
That have since amorous Ouid was exiled,
Lain in a swoon, you haue many holds for war,
I would once view a garrison for wit:
It were heavenly sport to see a train of scholars
Like old trained soldiers skirmish in the schools,
Traverse their Ergoes and discharge their jests
Like peals of small-shot, were this motion granted
Myself would be free woman of their hall,
And sit as sister at their festival.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Have we not Padua

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, but the commanders
Deal with our graduates, as the general
Doth with his soldier, gives him place for favour,
Not for deserving, look into it yourself,
You have Courts for tennis, and methinks it were meet,
Learning should not stand balling in the street
For want of house-room: O it is much unfit
Courtiers should be all pleasure and small wit.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: All that you speak is but what we command

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But Officers father cannot understand
Their Lords at first: wert not a gallant sight,
To see wits army royal come from fight?
Some crowned with gold, others with wreath of bays,
And whilst they hold their solemn holy days,
Music should like a lover court the skies,
And from the world wrest ringing plaudities.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: My sister would make a rare beggar.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: True, she is parcel Poet, parcel fiddler already, and they. commonly sing three parts in one.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Wrong neither art nor music, they are twins
Born and be got in heat, your thought of both.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I think my Lord that music is divine,
Whose sacred strains have power to combine
The soul and body; and it reason bears,
For it is said that the Celestial spheres,
Dance to Apolloes lyre whose sprightly fires
Have tamed rude beasts and charmed men's wild desires:
The author was immortal, the first strings,
Made by a King, therefore an art for Kings:
The world is a body, every liberal art
A needful member, music the soul and heart.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Well for her sex hath Florimell discoursed
Of heavenly music, and since all conclude
It is an art divine, we were too rude
Should we reject it, music, I take great pride,
To hear soft music and thy shrill voice chide.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: To please your grace, though I want voice and skill,
I will show myself obedient to your will.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This would have done rare at a scholars window,
How do you like it father?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Highly my boys, I relish all delight,
For when the fiery spirit of hot youth
Kept house within me, I was all delight:
Then could I take my love, no love more fair
By the smooth hand, and gazing in loves air
Tell her her beauty beautified the sky,
And that the sun stole lustre from her eye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I do admire to hear my princely father
thus merrily discourse of trifling love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Nay more my boys, when I was at your years,
I went a pilgrimage through Italie,
to find the shrine of some love-hallowed saint,
Devote to beauty, I would pray for love,
Desiring beauty I would sue for love,
Admiring beauty I would serve for love:
Pray, sue, and serve, till beauty granted love.
If she denied me I would swear she granted,
If she did swear that she could never love me,
Then would I swear she could not choose but love me:
Let her swear ne'er so much, still have I sworn,
Till she had said, I should not be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Aye marry brothers, here was cunning love,
Learn like good scholars, he will make you wise in love:
He was a man in love, were you such men,
Then were you men indeed, but boys till then.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: To please my Father, I will inquest of beauty,
And never make return till I have found,
A love so fair, so rich, so honourable,
As fits the honour of Octauioes sons.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The like (you pleased) vows young Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Do boys, and I will teach you how to choose them.
Elect not amongst whole troupes of Courtly dames,
For amongst many, some must needs be ill:
The seld seen Phoenix ever sits alone,
Ioue courted Danae when she was alone:
Alone my boys, that is the only way,
Ladies yield that alone, they else say nay.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: An expert soldier; how shall they choose them Father?

sp.speaker: 'Oct.
sp.l: If her bright eye dim not the Diamond,
Say it is bright, but brighter gems delight you,
If that her breath do not perfume the air;
Say it is sweet, but sweeter sweets content you.
If that her cheek compared to the Lily,
Make not the Lily black with whiter whiteness;
Say it is Lily white, but black to white,
When your cholle white must have such high exceeds.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Father you do exceed things possible,
Faith say how many Ladies have you seen,
Much fairer than myself, in all your travail?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Should the Crow teach me, then no Lady fairer,
If judgment tell me, then a many fairer:
Thou art mine own, I must think well of thee,
Yet Florimella many do excel thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Should the Crow teach, I am not all Crow black.
Though judgment; I not all perfection black,
Though you have seen Ladies that dim the day,
Yet will I think myself as fair as they.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Do Florimella, and I will one day get,
A husband for thee that shall think thee fair.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And time i'faith, that pretty sport would be,
Wive it for them, you shall not husband me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yet you will take my counsel in your choice.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, if I had not years enough to choose,
Would you direct me as you do your sons?
With daughter take a man with such a nose,
With such an eye, with such a colour beard,
Thus big, thus tall, with all his teeth afore;
Thus lipped, thus legged, thus handsome, thus appareled,
Were not this pitiful! o pitiful:
Now by the soul of sole-commanding love,
I will not stoop to such obedience,
I must be bid to blush when I am kissed,
Bid my love welcome, and I thank you sir,
With no indeed, I know not what love is,
I never heard so much of love before,
I pray take heed, nay fie you go too far,
With such a rabble of prescriptions,
As never maid of a Conceiving spirit,
Will follow them, yet brothers go you on,
Take you good counsel, Flormell will none,

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Aye daughter? are you so experienced?
An elder woman might have spoken less,
Yet by your leave minion, I will watch you so,
Your I shall still be governed by my no.
But come my sons take pattern of great Ioue,
Early in the morning suit yourselves for love.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Anthonio Duke of Mantua, Hermia and Lucida his daughters, they with angels and he with a net.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Go daughters with your Angels to the brooke,
And see if any silver-coated fish,
Will nibble at your worm-embowelled hooks:
Deceive the watery subjects, yet the name
Of foul deceit methinks should fray them from you,
Alack, alack, I cannot blame the world,
That in the world there is so much deceit;
When this poor simple trade must use deceit.
But with what conscience can I make this net,
Within whose meshes all are caught that come:
They cozen one at once, this cozens many,
I will undo it it shall not cozen any.
But daughters go practise that little sin,
I will mend this great fault ere the fault begin.
O cozening fortune how hast thou deceived me,
Turning me out a doors to banishment,
And made another Lord of Mantua.
I that was Lord now slave to misery.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Take comfort yet dear father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Comfort? no:
My breast is turned prison, my proud jailer woe,
Locks out all comfort: where is your valiant brother?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: All discontent like to a wounded lion
He forages the woods, daring proud fortune
At her best weapon, he accounts this smart,
As a 'slight hurt, but far off from the heart.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: How holds his humour?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The same fashion still:
But somewhat stragglers death may end
But never change him, see our words have raised him.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Fitly applied for he walks like a ghost.
Why how now son?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Brother.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Good now peace, Wake me not as you love me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What a sleep?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Aye, in a most sweet sleep, blisters on your tongues for waking me.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Thou forgetst thyself.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I should not be a Courtier else, methought I was at a strange wedding?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Prithee what wedding?

sp.speaker: 'Asp.
sp.p: Of a young Lawyer and old Madam Conscience.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: I scarce believe that.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Nor I neither, because it was a dream, but methought the young man doted on the old woman exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: That was miraculous! did they live together?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: In the country they did, and agreed passing well, all the long vacation, and but for two things he would have carried her up to the term with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What things were those?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: One was, because her gown was of the old fashion, the other was cause he would not have her by when he took fees.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: His reason for that?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: For fear if a bribe had been offered, she being by he should have had the bad conscience to take it.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: His wife and he lived together.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Conscience and the Lawyer, as lovingly as men and their wives do, one flesh, but neither meddle nor make one with another

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Man and wife part, that is strange!

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: O lord sir, profit can part the soul and the body, and why not man and wife, now you have had my dream father, let me understand yours.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: How can he dream, that never sleeps my son?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p:
O best of all: why, your whole world doth nothing but dream, your machiauell he dreams of state, deposing kings, grounding new monarchies: the lover he dreams of kisses, amorous embraces: the newly-married wife dreams,
that rid of her young husband she hugs her old love, and likes her dream well enough too: the Country gentlewoman dreams that when her first husband is dead, she marries a knight, and the name of Lady sticks so in her mind, that she is never at hearts-ease till she get her husband dubbed; the Captain, he dreams of oppressing the soldiers, devising strategies, to keep his dream, and that dream wakes in the pate of Octauio your Arch-enemy, who is not content to hurl us into the whirlpool of banishment, but binds weights at our heels leaden poverty, to sink us to the very depth that we should never rise again.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Then since all dream, let us dream of revenge.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Aye marry sister, that were a dream worth dreaming, and I will sleep out my brains but I will compass it.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Pretty content; we kill our foes in dreams.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Uds foot, I will do it waking then.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Aspero.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: At Counsel table.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: In his Duchess arms, it were base to go disguised,
No, my revenge shall wear an open brow;
I will not play the coward, kill him first
And send my challenge after; I will make known
My name, and cause of coming, if I thought
Grief like a painter had so spoiled my visage
He could not know me, on my breast i would write
How ever I am disfigured through woe,
I am the thing was made for Aspero.
Speak not, I am as constant as the Centre,
Some fortune good or bad doth beckon me,
And I will run, bitter revenge tastes sweet,
If ne'er on earth farewell, in heaven we will meet.
Attendance sirrah, your low Comedy,
Craves but few Actors, we will break company.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: As many blessings as the sea hath sands
Attend thee in thine honourable journey:
Come pretty maids we have not wrought today,
Or fish, or fast, our need must needs obey.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Hippolito, Francisco, Florimell, and Page meeting them.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Now sirrah what have you been about?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: About my living sir.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What is that? feeding?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No sir, looking into the under officers about the Court.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Canst get any living out of them?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Aye sir, my betters get good livings out of officers, and why not I? but to be plain, I have been seeking your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: But your boyship hath so sought us, that we have found you.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Will you sell your findings my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: They are scarce worth giving.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, a box to keep them in, for fear you lose them again.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: If I were a man as I am no woman, I would pepper your box for that jest.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You jest.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: In earnest law I would Madam.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Well sir, no more, here comes our royal Father.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: How now my boys? provided for your journey?
Beauty conduct you: what, attired like shepherds?
I thought to have seen you mounted on your steeds,
Whose fiery stomachs from their nostrils breath
The smoke of courage, and whose wanton mouths
Do proudly play upon their iron bits:
And you in stead of these poor weeds in robes,
Richer than that which Ariadne wrought,
Or Cytharaes airy-moving vestment.
Thus should you seem like lovers suited thus,
you would draw fair Ladies hearts into their eyes,
And strike the world dead with astonishment.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Father such cost doth pass your sons revenues
We take example from immortal Ioue,
Who like a shepherd would repair to love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: And gentle love conduct you both my sons,
Daughter go bring them onward in their way,
Were not we called back by important business,
We would not leave you thus: Hortensio
Is my disguise prepared, for I unknown
Will see how they behave themselves in love.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: It is done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Once more my boys adieu:
He sends you forth that means to follow you.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.l: Now brothers you must amongst these wenches,
Faith for a wager which shall get the fairest?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I will gage a hundred crowns mine proves the fairest.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A match, I will venture twice so much of mine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And I will lay against you both, that both your loves Get them when you can where you can, or how you can, shall not be able to compare with me in beauty.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That wager I will take for it is surely won.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Alas thou art but a star to beauties sun.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Star me no stars, go you and stare for love,
I will stay at home, and with my homely beauty
Purchase a love, shall think my looks as fair,
As those fair loves that you shall fetch so far;
But take your course, fate send you both fair luck.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: How if it be foul?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay if it be forked, you must bear it off with head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: O stale, that jest runs on the lees.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You must consider it is drawn out of the bottom of my wit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: O shallow wit, at the bottom so soon.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Deep enough to lay you in the mire.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Or else it is shallow indeed, for they are foundered already, but I must play dun, and draw them all out of the mire,
What is o'clock my Lord?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Which of them dost ask? thou seest they are two.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: What two are they Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why two fools.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Is it not past two, doth it not come somewhat near three sister:

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Show perryall and take it, but come my Lord you have stood fooling long enough, will you about your business in good earnest?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Indeed we will.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If they are deeds you must trust too, for women will respect your words but slightly without deeds.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why, are women called Angels but because they delight in good deeds, and love heaven, but that it will not be won without them.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: They shall have deeds.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Brother, and good deeds too: They are tongues that men must speak with when they woe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: That tongue we will practise, to love we leave you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Lovers take heed least cunning love deceive you.

div2.stage: Exit with Page. Finis actus primi.
ACTVS SECVNDVS. Enter Octauio disguised, Hortensio Flamineo.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: No more; thus suited I will attend my sons,
Impute it not to any ruffian vain,
But to a fathers wakeful providence,
Lovers like bees are privileged to taste,
All buds of beauty: should they chance to light
Upon some worthless weed I will hinder it:
The eyes of youth will now and then dwell there,
Whereas they should not glance, this doubt I fear.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And well advised my liege should they incline
To love not fitting their estates and births,
You with your present counsel may prevent them.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: That is my intent, and further in my absence
I leave my land and daughter to thy charge,
The girl is wanton, if she gad abroad
Restrain her, bound her in her chamber door;
My word is thy warrant, let her know so much:
Farewell, at home I leave my fear with thee
And follow doubt abroad.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I will careful be.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Now to my business, I have a strange habit, and I must cut out an humour suitable to it, and humours are picked so near the bone, a man can scarce get humour enough to give a flea his breakfast, but I am a stale ruffian, my habit is brave, and so shall my humour be, and here comes one to give me earnest of it.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Send him a letter that I come to kill him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It were great valour but little policy my Lord.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: How long have you been a matchiauilian boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ever since I practiced to play the knave my Lord.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Then policy and knavery are somewhat a kin.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As near, as penury and gentry, a degree and half removed no more.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: How came in the kindred betwixt gentry and penury?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Shall I tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: First tell me what thou art?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Lime and hair: plaster of Paris, kneaded together with rye dough and goats milk, I am of a hot constitution, will not freeze.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Thy profession.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: A fool or a knave choose you which.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then thou art fit for any gentleman's company.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: True boy, for your sweet fool and your five knave are like a pair of upright shoots, that gentlemen wear so long now of one foot, then of another, till they leave them never a good sole.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: That makes your fool and your knave have such bad soles; but what dost thou seek?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Mine own undoing sir, service.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Indeed service is like the common law, it undoes anyone that follows it long, canst describe service?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yes, it is a vacant place, filled up with a complete knave, a miserable pander, or an absolute beggar.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: your opinion boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I say a serving-man is an Antecedent.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Because he sits before a Cloak-bag.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is likewise a nominative Case, and goes before his mistress.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: That is when the verb he goes before his mistress and he can agree together.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If not, he turns Accusative and follows his master.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Would follow me fellow.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: To a tavern, and thou would pay for my ordinary.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: My business is more serious, thou dost not know me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nor myself neither so long as I have maintenance.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Didst never hear of the wars betwixt Venice and Mantua.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I cut some few of the Mantuans throats.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: And wert not a knave for it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, I was a Venetian commander, a great man: the reason of this question.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Dost know the Duke of Venice?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I am his right hand.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Would do me a message to him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Tell him I hate him, my name is Aspero, has banished my father, usurps his Dukedom, and I come to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Anthonioes son? vesfoot hast any gold.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Thy reason.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Shalt be revenged, give me money, I will be thy snail and score out a silver path to his confusion.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: No, my revenge shall be like my fathers wrongs in Aperto lend me any honest aid.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Pax of honesty, it goes a begging upon crutches, and can get relief out of few but scholars, I shall not kill him?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I would be thy death first.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yet you say you hate him.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Equal with my shame.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Make him chew a bullet then.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: No, though my state with poverty be tainted,
Mine acts and honour shall live still acquainted.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: True moulded honour I admire the temper
Of thy mild patience, that not all the wrongs
I laid upon thee can enforce thy spleen
To foul requital, had thy coming taken
Any base level, it had cost thy life,
But being free and full of honour live,
Thy virtues teach me honour freely go,
A secret friends worse than an open foe:
You are too honest for my attendance, farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: And thou too knavish for my employment.
But here comes more company.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Boy, let your attendance wait further off,
Under this shade I mean to take a sleep.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And may you madam like a soldier sleep.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How boy in alarums.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: No Lady but in arms, and you had need of them too, for see the enemy comes down, shall I sound a parley?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Peace wag.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Peace, O coward, offer peace and but two to two of them.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Boy dost know what gentleman it is?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Gentle madam no, but he is a man.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Believe me boy he is a proper man.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Man is a proper name to a man, and so he may be a proper man.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I love him he is a very proper man.

sp.speaker: Pa,
sp.p: She loves him for his properties, and indeed many women love men only to make properties of them.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray gentleman if no more, tell me where you were born.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Fair virgin if so much, nowhere somewhere anywhere, where you would have me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Faith I would have it.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Marry and you shall have it Lady.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What shall I have sir.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Why a kiss.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nothing else: we Courtiers count them trifles, not worth taking.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Why then bestow one of me I will take it most thankfully.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I will not stand with you for a trifle, sir pray where were you born?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: In Italy, but never yet in Venice.

sp.speaker: Elo.
sp.p: You may in Venice, gentle sir adieu.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Gentle Lady thrice as much to you.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Farewell sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: God a mercy bag pudding.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: You may in Venice gentle sir adieu? this begets wonder.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You are not wise then, what do you take her for?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Some great woman.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Some woman great with child, be ruled, she is a pink board her.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: But how? the means.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Make but a shot of flattery at her broad side, and she will strike sail presently.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Flattery?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Aye, flattery, women are like fiddlers, speak them fair they will play of any instrument.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Aye, that they can play of.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: She is a botcher cannot play a little of all.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: And too common that will play too much of any, but come I will use means to get her.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Nay you must first have means to give her.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Why in the course of scholarship, the genitive Case goes before the Dative.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Grammarians are fools that placed them so; for in Rerum Natura, the Dative goes before the genitive, you must always give before you can get, lovers are fools, and fools must be liberal.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Will not women respect a man for his good parts?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: yes, some few; but all for his good gifts, a gentleman with his good gifts sit at the upper end of the table on a chair and a cushion, when a scholar with his good parts will be glad of a joined stool in the Lobby with the Chambermaids.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I will have good gifts and show myself liberal to, though I beg for it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I think that will be the end, for penury has taken a lease of your pocket to keep Court in this Christmas.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Well, how so ever, she is fair and courteous,
And courteous fair, is a fair gift in Ladies:
She may be well descended, if she be,
She is fit for love, and why not then for me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If you be not fitted in Venice it is strange, for it is counted the best flesh-shambles in Italie: but here is no notable coward, that having suffered wrong by a man, seeks to right himself of a woman.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter Hippolito Francisco like shepheards, Octauio in disguise.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Look you sir, I am like an irish beggar, and an English bur, will stick close where I find a good nap, I must and will dwell with you.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: What canst do:

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Still Aquanitæ, stamp Crabs, and make mustard, I can do as much as all the men you keep,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Prithee what?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Why undo you, and twenty could do no more, but business, come my wits grow rusty for employment.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Canst keep counsel?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: My mother was a midwife.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Hast any skill in Love?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I am one of Cupids agents, have Ouids ars amandi ad vngues, know causam, and can apply remedium, and minister effectum to a hair, but why do you ask? have you traversed an action in loves spiritual court?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Not to dissemble, we have.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And without dissembling you will never come out of it, but tell me true, are you in love already? or have you but desire to be in love

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Indeed I am in love to be in love.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And I desire to live in fond desire,
And yet I doubt too much blind fancies fire.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: It is good to doubt, but it is not good to fear,
Yet still to doubt, will at the last prove fear;
Doubt love, it is good, but it is not good to fear it,
Love hurts them most, that least of all come near it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Then to doubt love is the near way to love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Doubtless it is if you misdoubt not love.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Doubt and misdoubt? what difference is there here?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Yes, much: when men misdoubt, it is said they fear.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: But is it good in love to be in doubts

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: No not in love, doubt then is jealousy:
It is good to doubt before you be in love,
Doubt counsels, how to shun loves misery.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Your doubtful counsel counsels us to love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: To equal love, I like experience speak.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Experienced lover, you have spoken well.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Experience wanting lovers, truth I tell,
Young wits be wise, in love live constant still,
You need nor doubt good hap nor misdoubt ill.

div2.stage: Enter Lucida and Hermonia with Angles.

sp.p: And see your discourse has conjured up beauty in the likeness of two country maids, but you shall not come in the circles of their arms if I can keep you out.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: These are too mean for love, brother let us leave them.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: What? speechless? will you make dumb virgins of them?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O we are sons of a great father.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: So is the sun of heaven, yet he smiles on the bramble as well as the Lily, kisses the cheek of a beggar as lovingly as a gentlewoman, and it is good to imitate, him it is good.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Say sister, had we not fine sport today?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: We had, if death may be accounted play.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why it is accounted pleasure to kill fish.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A pleasure nothing pleasant to the fish.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Yet fishes were created to be killed.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cruel creation then to have lives spilled.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Their bodies being food, maintain our breath.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What bodies then have we to live by death?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Come, come, you vainly argue, it is good.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What is it good to kill? o god o god?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: If it be sin, then you yourself is a sinner.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thank proud fortune fort, my woes beginner.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Foot are ye not ashamed to stand by like idle ciphers, and such places of account void? and they had been rich offices and you poor Courtiers, you would have been in them in half the time.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Though against stomach.---

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nothing against stomach and you love me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Fair maids if so, you be you are well met.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Shepherds or be what else you are well met.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: It is well, if that well met we be to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If not to us you are unto yourselves.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: We did not meet, you saw us come together.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Whatever we saw, you met ere you came hither.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: We did, we met in kindred, we are brothers.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So shepherds we did meet for we are sisters.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Then sisters, let us brothers husbands be.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: So brothers without our leaves you well may be.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Say we desire to husband it with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Know we desire no husbands such as you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A shepherd is an honest trade of life.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Yet honest shepherd has with honest trade some strife.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He seldom swears but by his honesty.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: So honest men do too as well as he.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: But will you trust a shepherd when he vows.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No never, if his oath be that he loves.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yet if I swear, that needs must be mine oath.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Swear not, for we are misbelievers both.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Let us persuade you to believe we love you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: First we entreat you give us time to prove you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Take time, mean time we will praise ye to our powers.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: O time, sometime shepherds have idle hours.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I will say thy cheek no natural beauty lacks.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good, if it had been spoke behind our backs.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I will say this is the heaven of heavenly graces.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: O heaven, how they can flatters to our faces.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Brother the last is fairest in my eye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Aye but the first brother is first in beauty.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: First in your choice, but not in beauty sir.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Come ye so near as choice: then it is time for me to stop for fear the music run too far out of tune, how now gallants? in dumps.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: No, but in love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: That is a dump, loves nothing but an Italian dump or a French brawl.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Methinks it is sweeter music.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And it were in tune I confess it, but you take your parts too low, you are treble Courtiers, and will never agree with these Country Mannikins, the music is too base, never meddle in it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Peace dotard, peace, thy sight of love is done,
Thou canst not see the glory of loves sun.
Spent age with frosty clouds thy sight doth dim,
That thou art blind to see and apt to sin.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Is it accounted sin to speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And worse, when age spits poison against youth.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: They do not fit your callings, let them go.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Yet they are fair: we love, thou art loves foe.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I am your friend, and wish you from this love.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Canst thou heave hills? then thou my thoughts mayst move, but never else.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Never!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: No never.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Stay.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: We are bound for love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Hate.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Hinder not our way.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Aye boys? will Eagles Eaglets turn to bastards.
Then must I change my vain, and once more prove,
To teach you how to hate as well as love.

div2.stage: ACTVS TERTIVS. Enter Page and Florimell.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Sweet honey candy madam, if it be no forfeit to tell tales out of Cupids free school, tell what proficient your lover Aspero proves.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Now so love help me lot, a passing weak one and very unready.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: The better, for women would have their lovers unready to choose.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How ready you are to play the knave? but to Asperot

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I do not think but there is good music in him, your tongue harps so much upon his name.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I shall never forget him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: In faith Lady then I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What do you know I pray?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Marry that if you never forget him, you shall ever remember him, was he never in your chamber?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, but he showed himself the strangest fool: And by my troth lo. I am sorry for it too, I had as good an appetite to maintain discourse; but here he comes, if ever I choose a man by the fullness of his Calf, or a cock by the crowing, look and the bashful fool do not blush already.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You may do well to kiss him, and make him bold Madam.

sp.speaker: Pa
sp.p: Boy, go know what strange gentleman that is.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: 'slid what a strange Lady is this? madam though I seem a stranger to you, I lay with one last night that is well acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Elo.
sp.p: Acquainted with me?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: And knows you, and loves you, and you love him, and have bestowed kind favours of him too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I bestow favours? what favours?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Though it were but a trifle he took it as kindly as some would have done a kiss.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Lord what a while this jest has been a brooding? and it proves but addle too now it is hatched.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: It is a pig of your own sow madam, and I hope your wit will bestow the nursing of it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: So it had need, I think it is like to have but a dry nurse of yours.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O dry jest, all the wit in your head will scarce make sippets in it, what a ground? and such a fair landing place? get a shore, or be ranked amongst fools for ever.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And faith is it not pity such a proper man should keep company with a fool.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I keep company with none but you Lady.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You keep mine against my will.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: So do I the fools I protest; but take away yours, I will soon shift away the fools.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I have not seen a fool so handsomely shifted in Venice.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: But come, shall the fool and you be friends?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The fool and I? you are too familiar.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Why, I hope a fool may be a Ladies familiar at all times.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Come you are too saucy.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Indeed it is a fools part of Ioue to be in the sauce afore my Lady; otherwise I am neither fool nor saucy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Not, proud sir?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Not, coy Lady; come why should your tongue make so many false fires that never come from your heart: you love me, I know you love me, your spirit, your look, your countenance bewrays it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You jest.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: In earnest you do, and you shall know it in earnest too, lend me this jewel.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Jewel? away you sharking companion.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Wandering extravagant, that like a drone flies humming from one land to another.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: 'slight and thou hast any wit, now show her thy sting.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And lightest upon every dairy maid and kitchen-wench.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: And now and then on a Ladies lip as---

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You did of mine you would say, and I am heart sorry you can say it, and when by your buzzing flattery, you have sucked the smallest favour from them, you presently make wing for another.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Marry buzz.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Double the zard and take the whole meaning for your labour.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The buzzards wit is not so bald yet I trow.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: A word in your ear, madam the buzzard will anger you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: With staying you do.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: With going I shall.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p:
Aye away, never entreat, it is too late, if you send after me, I will not come back, if you write to me, I will not answer, drown your eyes in tears, I will not wipe them, break your heart with
sighs, I will not pity you: never look, signs cannot move me, if you speak, it is too late, if you entreat, it is bootless, if you hang upon me, it is needless, I offered love and you scorned it, my absence will be your death, and I am proud of it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is he gon boy?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes faith Madam.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Clean out of sight?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: And out of mind too, or else you have not the mind of a true woman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Thou readest a false comment boy, call him again; yet do not, my heart shall break ere it bend.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Or else it holds not the true temper of woman hood, but faith tell me Madam, do you love him?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: As a Welshman doth toasted cheese, I cannot dine without him, he is my pillow I cannot sleep quietly without him; my rest, I cannot live without him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O that he knew it Lady.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He does, he would never have left me else, he does.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You called him fool, but methinks he proves a physician, has found the disease of your liver, by the complexion of your looks, but see he returns.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And now methinks I loath him more than I loved him go run for Hortensio my guardian, bid him come armed, that it is intent of treason tell him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: My Lady cannot choose but dance well, she is so full of pretty changes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I wonder you dare come in my sight, considering the wrong you did me.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I came I confess, but with no intent to see you I protest, and that shall be manifested by the shortness of my stay.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
It is too long and it were shorter than it is, will he not court me? not? nor speak to me neither? nay never ask pardon, it is too late, we shall have you come to my window one of these mornings with
music, but do not, my patience is too much out of tune, out of my sight I hate thee, worse than I loath painting, I hate thee, out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Enough, will you be a quiet woman yet? will you, speak afore my resolve take strength? will you, do but say you are sorry I ask no mends but a kiss, kindly, come: shall I have it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I will kiss a toad first.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: You will, remember this another time, a toad you will: I know thou lovest me, and I see the pride of thy humour; I do, and thou shalt know I do; half an hour hence we shall have you weeping on your knees, with O my Aspero would I had died when I rejected thee, but do, weep till I pity thee; a toad! I will make thee creep on thy knees for a kiss.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: you will.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Thy bare knees, I will, and go without it too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Out humoured? O I would sell my part of immortality.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: But to touch my hand, thou wouldst, I know thou wouldst.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O how spleen swells me? Help Hortensio, creep a my knees? Hotensio.

div2.stage: Enter Hortensio with his man Assistance.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: How fares my beauteous charge? weeping Lady? the law shall fetch red water from his veins that hath drawn blood of your eyes, is this the traitor?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Traitor? in thy disloyal throat thou liest.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O monstrous, he wishes you choked my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: How? choked?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Aye choked? for he wishes the traitor in your throat, and he is a very small traitor that is not able to choke a wiser man than your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Down with him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Aye, down with him, if he stick in your throat, and spare not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Do not kill him, though he deserves death yet do not kill him, only disweapon him; so.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: But madam.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I will not hear him, keep him; but keep him safe on your
lives, if he get away or miscarry in prison: as I am heir of Venice I will have your heads for it.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I warn you madam, if irons will hold him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Fie, fie, with a cord? here, bind him with my scarf, that will hold, and yet stand away, I will do it myself, I cannot trust him with you, lest you should let him sometime scape free: besides, you cannot use him according to the quality of his offence, and because I will glory in his bondage my chamber shall be his prison, let him have neither light meat nor drink, but what I provide him myself.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Your will is a law, we obey it madam.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: She knows me sure; well, though my joys be thrall, My comforts this, a speedy death ends all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O you are not gone then.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Here is a new kind of courting, never seen before I think.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He would anger me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nay you take a course, to anger him first I think.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Should I have let him go, (as I could no other way detain him in modesty) and he had set his love on some other, it would have fretted my heart strings a sunder.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why did you set him so light then?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Not for any hate, but in pride of my humour.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why did you command him close prisoner to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That I may feed mine eye with the sight of him, and be sure no other beauty can rob me of his company: I will have it all, I will not lose an inch of him: And in this, I but imitate our Italian dames, who cause their friends to clap their jealous husbands in prison, that if they have occasion to use them within forty weeks and a day, they may surely know where to find them.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: If I had any knavery in me, as I am all honesty, I could make a notable scene of mirth betwixt these two Amorists.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Early sorrow, art got up so soon?
What? ere the Sun ascendeth in the East?
O what an early waker art thou grown?
But cease discourse, and close unto thy work;
Under this drooping myrtle will I sit,
And work a while upon my corded net;
And as I work, record my sorrows past,
Asking old Time, how long my woes shall last:
And first, but stay alas what do I see?
Moist gum like tears, drop from this mournful tree
And see, it sticks like birdly me; it will not part;
Sorrow is even such birdly me at my heart.
Alas poor tree, dost thou want company?
Thou dost, I see it, and I will weep with thee,
Thy sorrows make thee dumb, and so shall mine.
It shall be tongueless, and so seem like thine;
Thus will I rest my head unto thy bark,
Whilst my sighs tell my sorrows; hark tree, hark.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Fie, fie, how heavy is light love in me?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How slow runs swift desire?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: This leaden air, This ponderous feather, merry Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: This passion, which, but in passion
Hath not his perfect shape.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And shapeless love
Hath in his watch of love overslept himself.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Then sleepy wakers, let these grave let us wander
And wait the ascension of beauties wonder:
But stay, a man striving betwixt life and death.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay then it is so, my heavenly love is gone by,
And struck him dead with her love-darting eye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It speech-bereaving love will let thee speak,
Then speechless man, speak with the tongue of love,
And tell me, if thou sawest not Cynthia
Seeking Endimion in these flowery dales.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Dales for Endimion and fair Cynthia fit,
But never heavenly goddess blessed this grove,
These woods are consecrate to grief, not love.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Out Atheist, thou profanest loves deity,
For, false-reporter, I in them have seen
A love that makes a Negro of Loves Queen:
One that when as the sun keeps holiday,
Her beauty clads him in his best array.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Now truly shepherd none such sojourn here
Please you survey the Cell, go in and see,
I am hearst, and none but sorrow lies with me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Call you this sorrows cave?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Rather a Cell,
Where pleasure grows, and none but Angels dwell.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To what compare shall I compare thee to?
Incomparable beauties Paragon.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will compare her beauty to the sun,
For her bright lustre gives the morning light.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I will say she is like Cynthia when day is done,
Or Lady to the mistress of the night.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O speak but to me, and I shall be blessed.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: One smile would lay my jarring thoughts at rest.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: How now fair sister? you are hard beset.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nymph.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Goddess.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Saint, once more, you are both well met.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O she is fair.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: She fairer.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Both more fair
Than rocks of pearl, or the chaste evening air.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Say sweet, intend you not to fish today?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No, shepherds, now fish do not bite but play.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: What time, sweet love, keep fishes when they bite?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Early in the morning, or else late at night.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Come, will you talk with me till time of fishing?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: My father, sir, will chide if I be missing.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: The match is made, they are even upon going.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What should we do?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Why as poor parents and dutiful servants should do, run amongst the bushes and catch flies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Stay forward daughters whether are ye going?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Father, I think these shepherds come a wooing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A wooing daughters? ne'er imagine so:
What man is so mad to marry grief and woe?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Why where lives sad grief? here is all speaking joy.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O I would live and die with such annoy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But they are poor, and poverty is despised:

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No, they are fair, beauty is highly prized.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: It will be a match, they are beating the price already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They once were fair, sorrow from that hath changed them
They once knew wealth, but chance hath much estranged them.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Have they been fair? what fairer than they are?
Why it is not possible, this heavenly fair
Hath only in itself beauties exceed,
O then rich, fair, and only selves exceed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come daughters, and come shepherds, if you please,
I will lead you to the lodge of little ease,
Where I will feast you with what cheer I may,
Grief shall turn mirth, and keep high holiday.

div2.stage: Exit cum filiabus. The brothers going out Octauio staies them.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: A word with you, you mean to marry these wenches.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And are going to contract yourselves.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And what say you to this?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: God speed you: I would have you marry on saint Lukes day.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Because I would offer at your wedding.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Come, thou art all envy, feed upon thy hate,
This day our quest of love shall terminate.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Not if I live, this malady of love,
Is grown so strong, it will not be driven out,
To see the folly of a doting father;
What toil I had to fashion them to love,
And how it is doubled to misfashion them.
They shall not wed, yet how shall I prevent it?
Fearing the event I have forethought a means,
And here it lies, swaggering becomes not age,
Now like the Fox, I will go a pilgrimage.
Frolic my boys, I come to mar your sport,
Your Country music must not play at Court.
But first, I will write back to Hortensio
For apprehension of young Aspero:
They have not yet dined, I will bid myself their guest
Religion beg? a fashion in request.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter Aspero and his boy.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Art sure she hates me boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: More than her death, I have been in her bosom sir, and this day she intends your execution.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: My execution! the reason of her hate?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Her humour, nothing but a kind of strange cross humour in that you rejected her love.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: That is not capital.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not to cross a great ones humour? no treason more great personages humours are puritans, they will as live endure the devil as soon as a cross, and can away with him better.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I will submit, ask pardon on my knee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Is your proud humour come down i'faith, your high humour that would not stoop an inch of the knees; I will help it up again, if it be but to uphold the jest; I must bring her as low ere I have done; O base, I would rather lay my neck under the Axe of her hate, than my sport under the feet of
her humour; but be counselled, I will teach you to prevent both; and perchance make her upstart humour stoop gallant too.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I will hold thee my best jewel if thou dost.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And pawn me as poor Lords do their jewels too, will you not? receive me; you shall counterfeit yourself dead.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: The life of that jest.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It may be she dissembles all this while, loves you, and puts on this show of hate of purpose to humble you: she may, and I believe---

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That most intelligencers are knaves, and some women dissemblers; being thought dead (as let me alone to buzz that into the credulous ear of the Court) if she have any sparks of love, they will kindle and flame bright through the cinders of her heart.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: If not,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If not, it will be a means for your escape: I will say you requested at your death to be buried at your native City: and what Courtier, if a Christian can deny that?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I am all thine, my humour is thy patient.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And if I do not kill it, I am not worthy to be your physician.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Florimell and hir Page.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Aye marry Lady; why now you credit your sex: a woman's honour or humour should be like a ship under sail, split her keel ere she vail.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I will split my heart ere my humour strike sail: here comes his Page, how now boy? how doth your master.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Well madam he.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Where none of your proud sex will ever come, I think: in heaven.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is he dead?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
See madam, and seeing blush, and blushing shame, that your ungentle humour should be the death of so good and generous
a spirit.

div2.stage: Discouer Aspero lying on a Table seeming dead.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Aspero dead!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: See madam, what a mutation

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I see too much, and curse my proud humour that was the cause of it: Aspero, kind soul, proud sullen Florimell, disdainful humour, that in one minute hast eternally undone me: I would not kiss the living substance, that being dead dote on thy picture: o I loved thee ever with my soul: O let me kiss this shroud of beauty: I would not accept thee living, that being dead on my knees adore thee: could kisses recover thee, I would dwell on thy lips: kneel till my knees grew to the ground, dear gentle Aspero she that procured thy death will die with thee,
And crave no heaven, but still to lie with thee.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I take you at your word Lady: Nay never recant, I have witness on it now: is your proud humour come down? could you not have said so at first? and saved me a labour of dying?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Lives Aspero?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Live quoth he? 'sfoot what man would be so mad to lie in his cold grave alone, and may lie in a warm bed with such a beautiful wife as this will be? Have I taken your humour napping i'faith?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Am I over reached?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: In your humour Madam, nothing else, and I am as proud on it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Do not flout me; if you do, I shall grow into my humour again.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: In jest.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: In earnest I shall, and then I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: You may: but and you do, I shall die again.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: In jest.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Nay in earnest madam, and then---

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
No more, thou hast driven me clean out of conceit with my humour, I love thee, I confess it, shalt be my husband, I will live
with thee, thou art my life, and I will die with thee.
What more I mean is coated in my look, If thou acceptest it, swear,

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I kiss the book.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Boy, run to the master of my Gundelo, and will him attend me after supper at the garden stairs, I mean to take the evening air, tell him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: It shall be done madam.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay if I say the word, it shall be done Aspero

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Look to yourself my Lord, I lay my life, my Lady means to steal you away tonight.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Away? I will call Hortensio, I will not be accessory to your felony madam.

div2.stage: Enter Hortensio and his man Assistance with a letter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The fool comes without calling.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: You shall know him by these signs.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Good figure, very good figure, for as the house is found out by the sign, so must this traitor be scented out by the token, up with the first sign good Assistance.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: A proper man without a beard.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: How? a proper man without a beard? we shall scarce find that sign in all Venice: for the properness of a man lives altogether in the fashion of his beard, good Assistance the next.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: Fair spoken and well conditioned.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: More strange: you shall have many proper men fair-spoken, but not one amongst twenty well conditioned, but soft, this should be the house by the sign, I must pick it out of him by wit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: As good say steal my Lord, what marrowbone of wit is your judgment going to pick now?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I must, like a wise Justice of peace, pick treason out of this fellow.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Treason?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Aye, treason madam; know you this hand?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My royal fathers:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Then whilst you and your fathers letters talk together, let
me examine this fellow: are you a proper man without a beard?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: My properness sir contents me: for my beard, indeed that was bitten the last great frost, and so were a number of Justices of peace besides.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: It is rumoured about the Court that your name is Aspero.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I am called Aspero.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Son to the Duke of Mantua that was.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: The duke of Mantuaes son that is.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Then the Duke of Mantua has a traitor to his son, lay hands of him and to close prison with him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Can he be closer than in my custody?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I do not think so madam, but your father has imposed the trust upon me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And dare not you trust me?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: With my head if you were my wife, but not with my profit, if you were my mother: will you along sir?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: With all my heart sir, see what your humour has come to now go my Lord? as willingly as a slave from the galleys: for as I shall have a stronger prison, so I shall be sure of a kinder and a wiser jailer.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Do you observe how he flouts you my Lord? that I had been his keeper but one night longer: but keep him close, if he escape (though against thy will) as I am a maid,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: A maid against your will.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Shalt pay as for it as thou didst for thy office.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: If he scape, hang me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I shall wish thee hanged, if he do not: treason! I may thank my peevish humour for it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam the Gundelo is ready.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Thou bringest physic when the patient is dead boy: our jest has turned earnest.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is he dead in earnest?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: As good, or rather worse, he is buried quick.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
O madam, many a good thing has been buried quick and survived again, I would be buried quick myself, if I might
choose my grave.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He is buried in close prison boy, he is known for the duke of Mantuaes son, and by my fathers letter attached for a traitor.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Good gentleman, if I be not sorry for him: who is his keeper?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The testy ass Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Vdsfoot let us enlarge him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Not possible boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Not possible it is we will cozen his keeper.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We cannot.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Cannot! we can: your father made a Lord of him, but be ruled by me, his daughter shall make a fool of him: you are not the first woman has made a fool of a wiser Lord than he is.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Shall he be cozened?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: As palpably as at the Lottery, my brains are in labour of the stratagem already.

div2.stage: ACTVS QVARTVS. Enter Anthonio, Francisco, Hippolito, Hermin, Lucida and Octauio disguisd,

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Sons of Octauio if your princely thoughts
Can stoop to such mean beauty, from this hand
Receive your wives, but should the Duke your father---

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Fear not old man, he was the means that breathed this spirit into us.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Wood us to this course.
But should he prove Apostate, deny
Love which he first enforced us to profess,
So firm are our inseparate affections,
To win our loves we would lose the names of sons.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Your father thanks you, but hot-sprighted youths,
Take counsel from experience, ere ye tie
The gordian knot which none but heaven can loose,
Crave his consent: when an imperial hand
Shakes a weak shed, the building cannot stand?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Not stand? it shall: not Ioue himself can ruin the ground-work of our love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Not Ioue!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Not Ioue,
Should a speak thunder than go boldly on,
Our love admits no separation.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Then to mine office: in the sight of heaven your love is chaste.

sp.speaker: Fra., Hip.
sp.p: As innocence white-soul.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And yours.

sp.speaker: Herm., Lucid.
sp.p: And ours.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Then lend me all your hands,
Whilst thus a fathers tongue forbids the bands.
Forgetful boys, but most audacious traitor,
That durst in thought consent to wrong thy Prince,
Out of my sight; no Land that calls me Lord,
Shall bear a weight so hateful as thyself:
Live ever banished, if (three days expired)
Thou or these lustful strumpets.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Father.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Boys;
If you be mine show it in obedience:
If (three days past) you live within my dukedom,
Thee as a slave I will doom unto the galleys,
And these thy brats as common prostitutes
Shall dry their lustful veins in the Bordello.
Come boys, to Court; he that first gave you lives,
Will to your births provide you equal wives.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: They have our loves.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Our oaths.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Our hearts and hands.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Tut, lovers oaths, like toys writ down in sands
Are soon blown over, contracts are common wiles,
To entangle fools, Ioue himself sits and smiles
At lovers perjuries, bawd, strumpets hence,
My bosom is charged, give way to violence:
Come do not mind them.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How? not mind them father?
When in your Court you courted us to love,
You red another lecture, women then
Were angels.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: True, but that was before Angels
Had power to make them devils; they were then
Fiends to themselves, and Angels unto men.
When upon Po thou findest a cole-black swan,
Thou hast found a woman constant to a man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: And not afore?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Never afore.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your tongue
Unspeaks your former speech.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: It doth; new themes
Must have new change of Rhetoric; all streams
Flow not alike one way; when I spake like a lover,
It was to break you from your soldiers humour;
Having made you lovers, I, like Envy, speak
To make you hate love; Art still strives to break
Bad to make better:

sp.speaker: Brothers.
sp.p: You have your wish.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Then onward to the Court,
Make us of love, as schoolboys do of sport.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Florimell and her Page.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Call out the jailer boy, yet do not; hast got a beard like Hortensio?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I have got his hair, if I could come as easily by his wit.

sp.speaker: Elo.
sp.p: Wouldst rob him of his wit?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: If I should, he could not hang me for it it is not worth thirteen pence half penny but what shall I do with it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Put it on boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: That shall I madam, O forward age, I am a man already: how do you like me Lady?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Very ill, and my plot worse.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Then leave it off, if you be grounded in the plot,
You will but mar the Comedy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I purposed, thou in the habit of Hortensio, shouldst under pretence of removing Aspero to a new prison, have freed him out of the old one.

sp.speaker: Pa
sp.p: Tut, I can tell you a trick, worth two of that: madam, your care, take some care in the managing, and let me alone to prepare it.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Aspero and his Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Vdsfoot break prison my Lord, it is but swimming the River.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Break prison? it were both dishonour to my name, and treason to my love, what benefit were it for me to free my body, and leave my heart in bondage? I will die, ere I will harbour a disloyal thought.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: It bears no relish of disloyalty: being in prison you live as far from love as liberty: being abroad, you may by letters, or a thousand means purchase her company, and compass your content.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Shalt be my Lawyer boy and counsel me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will look for my Fee then.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: If thy Counsel prospers.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That is an exception Lawyers never respect, but come my lord, leap, as we have risen together, we will fall together.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Blame me not love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Vdsfoot your jailer my lord.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Am I prevented?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes faith, there had been a Counsellors fee cast away now.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: You have heard his usage Lady, seen his lodging, and if it please you, you both may and shall confer with him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Prithee call him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord, your keeper hath brought a Lady or two to see you.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: To see me? why am I turned monster? doth he take money to show me? what doth he take a piece trow?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why how now gallant, not gone yet?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Not, I thank you Lady, and yet I was near it.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: How do you man?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Musty for want of airing.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We will have you hanged out in the fresh air, one of these mornings.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: You would be glad to take me in then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, when you had hanged abroad a little: but my Lord Hortensio (for I think I must be your Lady when all is done) what sport? I would be merry a purpose to make him mad; the room is private and fit for any exercise.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Vdsfoot to her, can a woman offer fairer for it?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Why shall we go to span-counter madam?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: To span-counter, best ask her and she will go to Coits.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, I love some stirring exercise, my body is conditioned like the sun; it would never be out of motion.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I have it i'faith, when I was student in Padua,
We used a most ingenious pastime.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The name my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I cannot give it a name equal to the merit.
It is vulgarly called Blindmans buff.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Blind man's buff? ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Do you laugh at it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: At the happiness of your wit my Lord, that you should hit upon that sport, which of all other I delight in.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Will you hear an Apology I made in the commendation of it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
Pa.
sp.p: Who but the Author?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I, I, none shall be blind but I; help off with my gown boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What shall we have to blind him?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My scarf, take my scarf my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: There is a simple favour for you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: And most fit, for indeed nothing blinds lovers sooner than Ladies favours, but who shall blind me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Marry that will I my Lord, let me alone to blind you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Good again; for who should blind men, but beauteous women? come sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But how if you take me? as I know that will be your aim,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: If I take you prisoner madam, you must either be hoodwinked yourself, or give your conqueror a kiss for your ransom.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: An easy ransom: I will not be prisoner long, if a kiss will enlarge me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
Hort.
sp.p: As a purblind Poet: have amongst you blind Harpers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Methinks he looks for all the world like God Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Take heed of his dart madam, he comes upon you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He cannot come too fast, O I am taken prisoner.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Your ransom is but a kiss.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is that your law of arms?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Yes madam, but I will take it on your lips.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My lips like faithful Treasurers shall see it discharged.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: And here are my honest receivers to take it.

div2.stage: The Page puts his Pantoflle to his lips, he kisses it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Am I freed now?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: As if you had served seven year for it: sweet kiss, rare lip.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Has she not a sweet breath my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: As perfume.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And a soft lip?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p:
And smooth as velvet: I could scarce discern it from
velvet: i would pawn my office for the fellow on it, madam.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Here Aspero, on with this beard and gown: I think he follows me by the sent, his hat, so: a narrow miss i'faith my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Gone madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Even upon going, one of you counterfeit my voice, there I deceived you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Have you deceived me madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Not yet, but I will, and you look not the better to it, busy him till you think we are out of the Court, and then follow us: you shall find us at the south port, now or never my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Why then it will never be Lady.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Scaped again?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She is scaped indeed my Lord, you may cast your cap after her, for I see you can do no other good upon her.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: What have I catched you?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Kiss her and let her go.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Kings truce till I breath a little.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And you had need so, for I think you are almost out of breath, if you be not, you shall be, and that is as good, but breathe and spare not.

div2.stage: Enter Aspero like Hortensio, Florimell, and Assistance on the vpper stage.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Did you ever converse with a more stranger dissolute, madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Peremptory iacke, jailer, as you respect your office, lay special watch that none of what degree soever have access to him.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Without me.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: Or your signet.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p:
Signet me no signets, your goldsmiths shop is like your Swans nest, has a whole brood of signets, and all of a feather, and amongst many, one may be like another, let none enter upon the
stage where Aspero plays the madam, without Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: Is he mad my Lord?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: As the Lord that gave all to his followers, and begged more for himself.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If he call for me, tell him I scorn him.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: If he counterfeit my voice (as mad fellows will counterfeit great men's hands, and their tongues too) rate him for it, threaten him with the whip.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But come not at him.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: If he call for meat promise him fair;

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But give him none.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: If for light.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He may fire the house, let him have none.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: If he chafe, laugh.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If he rail, sing.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: If he speak fair, flout him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Do anything to vex him.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: But nothing to content him, you hear my charge, as you respect your office regard it.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: I warn you my Lord, let me alone, and we knew not how to abuse a prisoner, we were not worthy to be a Jailer.

div2.stage: Exeunt. They renew Blindmans Buffe on the Lower stage.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Are you in breath my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: As a bruers horse, and as long-winded; look to yourself madam, I come upon you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am ready for you sir, O for a bulrush to run a tilt at his nose.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A fair miss i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I will mend it next course you shall see.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: In the corner of the left hand; vdsfoot ware shins my Lord,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Where?
Help me up Madam.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O strange, cannot you get up without help? there is my glove, but come no nearer, as you love me.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I do love you madam.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O blind love.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: True madam; your beauty has made me blind.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Indeed loves sons like spaniels are all born blind.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: But they will see.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not till they be nine days old my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: But will you give me the fingers that hold this glove madam?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And the whole body to pleasure you my Lord, but let me go a little.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I will not lose you yet Lady.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But you shall my Lord; hist, then keep me still.

div2.stage: He fastens the gloue to a post.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Faith let go my Lord, for she grows sullen, and you had as good talk to a post, and as good answer it would make you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p:
Nay but dear madam, do but answer me, may I presume, upon my knees I beg it; but to take a favour from your sweet lips? shall I? I as I am not the first man, that love has blinded. may I presume? I would be loath to offend your mild patience so much, as with an unreverend touch: speak; if I shall reap the harvest of my honest desires, make me blessed in proposing the time when; what? not a word? are you displeased? or shall I take your silence for a consent? shall I? speak; or if modesty lock in your syllables, seal my assurance with a kiss: not? neither? shall I have neither your word nor your bond? nay then I must make bold with modesty; by this kiss madam, O my hard fortune? have I made suit to a post all this while? what block but I, would have been so senseless? my excuse is, it was but to make my Lady sport: and: Madam? how? Lady? madam? boy; madam, Aspero: but whist, I have the conceit, it was excellent in my Lady, and I applaud it, suppose my Lady and her prisoner had an intent of private business in the next room; was it not better in her to blind me, then I should as gentlemen ushers (cases so standing) have
blinded myself? again, I applaud her, and adore my stars that made me rather a blind than a seeing door-keeper: shall I interrupt them? no: madam? they have not done yet, sure they have not: what have we here? a base viol! though I cannot tickle the manikin within, I will (though it be somewhat base) give them a song without, and the name of the Ditty shall be;
sp.stage:
The Gentleman Vshers Voluntarie.
He sings.
sp.l: Peace, peace, peace, make no noise,
Pleasure and fear lie sleeping?
End, end, end your idle toys,
Jealous eyes will be peeping.
Kiss, kiss and part, though not for hate for pity,
Ha done, ha done, ha done, for I ha done my ditty.
And if you have not done now too, let me be as base as my fiddle, if I rouse you not: madam for shame,
