what do you mean to make of me, how? 'sfoot what have you made of me already? all gone? Jailer?

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: How now? who calls?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Why saucy knave it is I.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: You, what you?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: A single V, I came in double, but I thank them, they are gone out, and left me here a single.---

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: Fool, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Knave, I am Hortensio, I charge thee let me out.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: Fool, you lie, you are Aspero, and I have charge to keep you in.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: From my Lord Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: 'sfoot knave I tell thee I am he, and thou wilt not believe me, trust thine eyes, come in and see.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: It will not serve your turn, I like a whole skin better than a pinked one: content yourself tonight, and in the morning I will tell you more.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Where is my Lady, send her hither.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: She is busy with my Lord Hortensio, but if you have any use for a woman, I will send you one of the Laundresses: fare you well sir, be content, you shall want nothing of anything you have.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Hortensio gone outland my Lady busy with Hortensio? I am gulled, palpably gulled: whilst I like a block stood courting the post, Aspero is in my apparel escaped: villains, traitors, open the door, the Duke is abused, his daughter has fled: I proclaim ye all traitors that hinder me in the pursuit.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: O for a reasonable audience to applaud this scene of merriment: I will go call my Lady and my Lord Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Blindmans buff? I have buffed it fairly, and mine own gullery grieves me not half so much as the Dukes displeasure, jailer, not a word? jailer, there is no way to please a knave but fair words, and gold: honest kind jailer, here is gold for thee: do but take pity upon me, a miserable cony-catched Courtier: not? neither fair nor soul? thou art a degree worse than a woman; what shall I do? I can compare my fortune and my unfortunate self to nothing so fitly as my Base here, we suffer every fool to play upon us for their pleasure: and indeed it was the intent of our Creator that made fiddles and servitors to nothing but to be played upon, and played upon we shall be, till our heart strings crack, and then they either cast us aside or hang us up, as worthy no other employment; well, if I can work my means, of escape, so: if not, I must lie by it.

div2.stage: ACTVS QVINTVS. Enter Octavio, Francisco, Hippolito Flamineo &c.

sp.l: My daughter fled? and with Hortensio,
It bears no formal shape of likelihood,
Her Eagle spirit soared too proud a pitch,
To seize so base a pray; let privy search
Look through the cities bosom till they find her:
For gone she is not.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Has not Anthonies son
Sent them by some base practise to their death?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: His breasts too full of honour; trusty Iulio?
What weighty business draws thee from thy charge?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Came not the cause afore me? the proud Mantuans
Basely revolt, deposed me from the seat
And chair of Regentship, sending in quest
Of proud Anthonio their late-banished Duke,
Him if they find or Aspero his son
sp.p: They will reinstall him in the regiment.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Him let them seek in the vast shades of death, as for his son.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: He is sure enough my Lord; he was a mad knave when he came in, but I think, I have made a tame fool of him by this time: for he has neither had bread nor water these four and forty hours.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: More villain thou.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: My Lord, Hortensio was the villain, he left such command with me, he is the wheel that turns about, and I a Country Iack must strike when I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Although my foe, he is honourably tempered,
Yet armed against my life go call him forth,
Guard in my safety with a ring of steel,
And mark how proudly he will demean revenge.

div2.stage: Enter Assistance and Hortensio bareheaded with his Crowd.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: Goblins, spirits, furies, fairies, the prison is haunted.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: With a knave is it not?

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: Yes, and an old fool my Lord, in the likeness of Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Villain where is Aspero.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: I know not my Lord: I let him in and my Lady to laugh at him, and it seems, he consented to treason, and let him out in his apparel.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: They consented together to cozen me, for taking delight (as my betters may do) in a foolish pastime called Blindmans buff, they stole away my gown, escaped the prison, and left me in fools paradise, where, what song I have played, my Viol can witness, they made me a little better than a bawd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: In act:

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Not merely in act: sed cogitatione, and id satis est vt inquit Suetonius.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Is he escaped: and Florimell with him?
Hortensio thy head shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I pray let my tongue be my heads Attorney, and plead my excuse.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Urge no excuse, away with him to prison.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: It shall be done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nay you sir too, shall taste of the same sauce, away with both.

sp.speaker: Flamineo.
sp.l: Come my sons,
Let us levy present arms against Mantua.
Being scarce come home we must abroad again,
The Common good is a careful Princes pain.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Anthonio, Lucida, Hermia and Lords.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: You that in all my banished pilgrimage,
Would never alienate your natural loves,
But in desire to see me re-installed,
Have thrust out proud Octauioes substitute,
And seated me in ancient dignity,
I am yours, and ready at your best dispose.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Your own, my liege, we like inferior lights
Take life from your reflection, for like stars
Unto the sun, are Counsellors to Kings:
He feeds their orbs with sier, and their shine
Contend to make his glory more divine.
And such are we to great Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The veins and arteries of Anthonio
Through which the blood of greatness flows in us.
Our life, and cause efficient of our state,
And these our pretty partners in exile.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: We ha yet performed but the least part of duty,
Your reinstalment: it rests, that with our blood,
We keep out innouasiue violence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You new-create me, and breath second life
Into my dying bosom, knew my son
Of this unlooked for Fortune, but ill Fate
Has played the Traitor, and given up his life
To coward treason.

div2.stage: A shout within. Enter Aspero and Florimell with their Pages.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Vdsfoot what offence have I committed against the state, that these iron-handed Plebeians so applaud me for?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: It is a sign they love you.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I had rather thy should hate me, it makes me suspect my bosom, for they love none, but the masters of factions, treasons, and invasions.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then you do not love the Commons.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Yes, as wise men do their flattering wives, only for show: the popular voice is like a cry of bawling hounds, and they get the foot of a fantastic and popular-affecting statesman, they never leave him, till they have chased him into disgrace, and then, like hounds, are at a loss, and with their loss, see, I have found my father, safety attend you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Welcome thou hope of Mantua and of us,
We now are honours new-beginners boy,
And may we better thrive then heretofore.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Never doubt it father, I have attractive stuff that will draw customers.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: What Lady is that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: One that has played the part of a Constable, brought you home a Runaway.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: A friend of mine Father, but daughter to your Archenemy.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Octauioes daughter?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Yes faith, you are out with the Father, and I will see if I can fall in with the daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And am I not a good child to leave my fathers love at six and seven, and hazard my honour upon your sons naked promise, and your hopeful acceptance.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: She has followed me through much danger.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: The better welcome, I love her for it.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Like her if you please, I would have nobody love her but myself.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And Lady, though your Father be our foe,
The virtuous love betwixt our son and you,
May nevertheless retain his sympathy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shall nevertheless retain his sympathy,
Anthonio know I am loves resolute,
Confirmed and grounded in affection:
I loved your son, not for he was a Prince,
But one no better than his present fortunes,
I will love him still, since first I loved him so,
Let Father, friends, and all the world say no.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: There is mettle Father, how can we choose but get cocking children, when father and mother too are both of the game.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: To arms my Lord, Octauio comes in arms
To give a proud assault unto the City.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Proud his assault, as proud be our resist,
Vie shot for shot, and stake down life for life,
Our breast is as bold as theirs, our blood as deep,
All that we will lose, or this our gettings keep.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Come brother, talk not of devouring war,
Say messenger, comes not Octauioes sons?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
They do, as proudly as the morning Sun
Beating the azured pavement of the heaven.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Then fear not father, my sister and myself,
Will be your champions and defend the City.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why Ladies, have you such large interest in our brothers.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Princess, we have, within there: reach our shields,
When beauty fights, the God of battle yields.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Francisco, Hippolito, Flamineo, Iulio. Enter Anthonio, Aspero, Florimell, two Pages Lords and Messenger aboue.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They offer parley, let me answer them.
Brothers, how now? who made you soldiers?
Faith even my father as he made you lovers:
What? hath he changed your shepherds hooks to swords?
Of Amoradoes made you armed knights?
O seldom-seene metamorphosis! I have known
Soldiers turn lovers, but for amorous lovers
To re-assume their valour, it is a change,
Like winter-thunder, and a thing as strange.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Our sister prisoner?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Tell me Florimell,
Dost thou live there enforced, or of free-will?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Free will, brothers, mine own freewill, all free in Mantua, here is freewill i'faith, speak am I not a free-woman?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: As if you had served for it, any man may set up under her copy without a protection.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Aye wag? are you there too?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes faith my Lord, my Lady has had my attendance to a hair.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You lie boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: If not mine, some bodies else: there is one has done---

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: What have I done sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nay nothing, but what my Lady was very well content with.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why sister, shame you not to set your love
On one, that is our Fathers enemy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shame? not a whit: but come, your wenches brothers,
I make no question, I have won my wager:
Are they as fair as I?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Leave that to trial.
Aspero make surrender of our sister.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: And have her in quiet possession? what do you think me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: We think thee a proud villain and our foe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: By heaven, they are villains all that think him so.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why do you love him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I should curse myself
if I should hate him:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Bring the ladders forth,
Bravely assault to separate their lives.

div2.stage: As they are scaling the walls, the Ladies come forth.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Stand proud Francisco.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Stand! O excellent word in a woman!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hold Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Hold! up with that word, and it is as good as the other.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What nymph or goddess in my Hermiaes shape,
Stands to debar my entrance to the town?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Madam, I wonder they enter not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why boy it seems they dare not.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O cowards and have two such fair breaches already.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Immortal Pallas that art more divine,
In my loves beauty that thou clothest thee in,
Withdraw thyself, and give our fury limits.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I will, but first Francisco take my shield.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And mine as challenge to a single combat,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Read the conditions and return your answers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well done i'faith wenches, O that the old gray-beard my Father were here, i would have about with him as I am honourable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Whats here!
A shepherd wooing of a Country maid,
As she sits angling by a Rivers side,
By them an aged man making a net!
The Motto: Sic! this Emblems moral is,
The former love I had with Lucida,
And this hope tells me that is fair. Lucida.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother, my shield the like presents to me,
But holds far more familiar reference,
Here doth the amorous shepherd kiss the Nymph;
Which she with a chaste blush consents unto:
And see, a gloomy man, clad like a pilgrim
Comes in, and separates their sweet delights:
The Motto, Sic! Aye so my Father came,
and banished me from beauteous Hermia,
and this hope tells me is fair Hermia.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: The more I look, the more methinks it is she.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: The more I think the more I find it is she.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: What should I think to prove it is not she?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Look, think, find, prove, do what you can,
These are the wenches that you courted then:
Then honey bees lay by your smarting stings,
and buzz sweet love into your Ladies ears,
Tell them of kisses, and such pretty things,
These drumming dub adubs loves pleasure fears.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: O heaven, o fortune, and most happy stars,
Do I find love, where I expected wars?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Aye that but now was all for war and death, am made all love, wars humour is out of breath.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: How, my sons love the daughters of my foe! it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Then question them yourself.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Why how now sons, is this your worth in arms.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Why are we not in arms father.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes, and in such arms as no Coward, but would venture life to march in.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Then boys, you love the daughters of Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: We liked them first.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: We will keep than liking stilt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And you will love them.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Father in faith they will.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Aye, runaway? are you there? whom has your Ladyship got to your husband?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: One that I stumbled on at Blindman buff, a proper man, a man every inch of him: and you would say so, if you knew but as much as I---meane to know ere I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Is he not son unto Anthonio?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Great Duke I am, and prostrate on my knee,
I beg a peace, which if your spleen deny,
I proudly stand where erst I mildly kneeled,
and cast down bold defiance from these walls.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: No more: your loves make my proud heart ashamed,
Your consort is sweet, and I will not be a mean
To make it jar: what my sons like shall stand,
By my consent, allowed and perfected;
all hate is banished, and revenge lies dead.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Then stead of spears, let Hymens torches flame
With hallowed incense, and the God of sprite,
Swell up your veins with amorous delight:
and so shut up our single Comedy,
With Plautus phrase: Si places, plaudite.
